alex,

that may be what the http spec says, but i don't believe
that's up-to-date with the thinking that's currently going
on in the web architecture area, in which uri are *identifiers*
primarily and may also be locators, names or whatever.

identity is a key principle here, not to be eclipsed by
something you may have found in the letters of the http
spec, the language of which is not always the most fortunate
from the architecture perspective.

since the nature of Jan's question was in the REST domain,
not in the HTTP domain, if we must split hairs, then I feel
an architecturally scoped answer is more appropriate than
a purely HTTP protocol scoped answer.  But we can let Jan
decide that.

Regards,
Walden

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
Cc: <jalgermissen@...>; <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 11:27 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource


: An HTTP URI simply designates a location at which
: data MAY be retrieved via the HTTP protocol.
: NOTHING ELSE.
:
: If I tell you "My address is 555 Maple Drive."
: The meaning of "555 Maple Drive" is not that it is
: my home.  "555 Maple Drive" simply designates a
: location. Whether I in fact reside at that
: location is irrelevant to its meaning.
:
: HTTP URIs are locators.  They have no other
: meaning in and of themselves.
:
: -Alex-
:
: ___________________________________________________________________
: S. Alexander Jacobson                      Check out my new blog!!!
: 1-212-787-1914 voice                       http://alexjacobson.com
:
:
:
:
: On Wed, 1 Oct 2003, Walden Mathews wrote:
:
: > Jan,
: >
: > The two questions are closely related.  Suppose you know I've
: > been renovating my house for the last 4 years, and you're interested
: > in that project.
: >
: > Suppose I (the author) assign a URI as an identifier of the concept
: > "Walden's house renovation", and give you that URI.
: >
: > Suppose that you use a browser or whatever to deference that URI
: > periodically over a span of several years.  Suppose that each time
: > you do so, you retrieve a different "document" in response, each one
: > representing at the time of dereferencing the project under study.
: >
: > Note that if each document so served required its own URI, then
: > there would be no identity at the level of my project, only identity
: > of documents representing it.  That would not serve your interest in
: > my project as well as having an identifier that targets the project
: > directly.
: >
: > As the "author", I assign the URI, and then manage the implementation
: > such that the representations all support a "sameness" of subject.  Roy
: > uses the word "semantic" there.
: >
: > Regards,
: >
: > Walden
: >
: > ----- Original Message -----
: > From: <jalgermissen@...>
: > To: <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
: > Sent: Wednesday, October 01, 2003 9:32 AM
: > Subject: [rest-discuss] REST's Definition of Resource
: >
: >
: > :
: > : Hello--
: > :
: > : I have some questions regarding REST's definition[1] of resource:
: > :
: > : REST (re-)defines resource to be an abstraction not only of a)
: > : information
: > : resources (e.g. Web pages) but also of a) services and b) abstract
: > : concepts.
: > : While I see a clear reason for the neccessity of b) for REST to be an
: > : architecture suitable for distributed systems I cannot see a reason
for
: > : c). IMHO,
: > : abstract concepts are not within the realm of distributed systems but
: > : are
: > : subject to knowledge representation/information management (in other
: > : words:
: > : subject to possible applications of the architectural style, but not
: > : part
: > : of the architecture itself).
: > :
: > : Can anyone explain to me, why REST actually re-defines 'resource' to
: > : include
: > : c) ?
: > :
: > : The second question I have is related to the question what the
: > : semantics of a resource are.  Roy's dissertation says:
: > :
: > : "REST accomplishes this by defining a resource to be the
: > :  semantics of what the author intends to identify, rather
: > :  than the value corresponding to those semantics at the
: > :  time the reference is created."
: > :
: > : To me this seems to contradict the idea of authorities defining the
: > : semantics of resources.  What is the precise meaning of 'author' here?
: > : Author of a 'document' that uses a particular URI or the author that
: > : somhow 'brings into being' a particular resource?
: > :
: > : Thanks,
: > :
: > : Jan
: > :
: > : [1]
: > :
http://www.ics.uci.edu/~fielding/pubs/dissertation/evaluation.htm#sec_6_2
: > :
: > :
